remarks.p: The OSCAL Control SSP format can be used to describe the information typically specified in a system security plan, such as those defined in NIST SP 800-18.
The root of the OSCAL System Security Plan (SSP) format is system-security-plan.

define-assembly.name: metadata
define-assembly.description: Provides information about the publication and availability of the containing document.

define-field.name: title
define-field.description: A name given to the document, which may be used by a tool for display and navigation.

define-field.name: published
define-field.description: The date and time the document was published. The date-time value must be formatted according to RFC 3339 with full time and time zone included.

remarks.p: This value represents the point in time when the OSCAL document was published. Typically, this date value will be machine generated at the time the containing document is published.

In some cases, an OSCAL document may be derived from some source material in a different format. In such a case, the published value should indicate when the OSCAL document was published, not the source material. Where necessary, the publication date of the original source material can be captured as a named property or custom metadata construct.

A publisher of OSCAL content can use this data point along with its siblings last-modified and version to establish a sequence of successive revisions of a given OSCAL-based publication. The metadata for previous revisions can be represented as a revision in this object.

define-field.name: last-modified
define-field.description: The date and time the document was last modified. The date-time value must be formatted according to RFC 3339 with full time and time zone included.

remarks.p: This value represents the point in time when the OSCAL document was last updated, or at the point of creation the creation date. Typically, this date value will be machine generated at time of creation or modification.

In some cases, an OSCAL document may be derived from some source material in a different format. In such a case, the last-modified value should indicate the modification time of the OSCAL document, not the source material.

A publisher of OSCAL content can use this data point along with its siblings published and version to establish a sequence of successive revisions of a given OSCAL-based publication. The metadata for previous revisions can be represented as a revision in this object.

define-field.name: version
define-field.description: A string used to distinguish the current version of the document from other previous (and future) versions.

remarks.p: A version string may be a release number, sequence number, date, or other identifier suffcient to distinguish between different document versions. This version is typically set by the document owner or by the tool used to maintain the content.

While not required, it is recommended that OSCAL content authors use Semantic Versioning as a format for version strings. This allows for the easy identification of a version tree consisting of major, minor, and patch numbers.

A publisher of OSCAL content can use this data point along with its siblings published and last-modified to establish a sequence of successive revisions of a given OSCAL-based publication. The metadata for previous revisions can be represented as a revision in this object.

define-field.name: oscal-version
define-field.description: The OSCAL model version the document was authored against.

remarks.p: Indicates the version of the OSCAL model to which this data set conforms, for example 1.1.0 or 1.0.0-M1. That can be used as a hint by a tool to indicate which version of the OSCAL XML or JSON schema to use for validation.

define-assembly.name: revision
define-assembly.description: An entry in a sequential list of revisions to the containing document in reverse chronological order (i.e., most recent previous revision first).

define-field.name: title
define-field.description: A name given to the document revision, which may be used by a tool for display and navigation.

define-field.name: published
define-field.description: The date and time the document was published. The date-time value must be formatted according to RFC 3339 with full time and time zone included.

remarks.p: This value represents the point in time when the OSCAL document was published. Typically, this date value will be machine generated at the time the containing document is published.

In some cases, an OSCAL document may be derived from some source material in a different format. In such a case, the published value should indicate when the OSCAL document was published, not the source material. Where necessary, the publication date of the original source material can be captured as a named property or custom metadata construct.

A publisher of OSCAL content can use this data point along with its siblings last-modified and version to establish a sequence of successive revisions of a given OSCAL-based publication. The metadata for previous revisions can be represented as a revision in this object.

define-field.name: last-modified
define-field.description: The date and time the document was last modified. The date-time value must be formatted according to RFC 3339 with full time and time zone included.

remarks.p: This value represents the point in time when the OSCAL document was last updated, or at the point of creation the creation date. Typically, this date value will be machine generated at time of creation or modification.

In some cases, an OSCAL document may be derived from some source material in a different format. In such a case, the last-modified value should indicate the modification time of the OSCAL document, not the source material.

A publisher of OSCAL content can use this data point along with its siblings published and version to establish a sequence of successive revisions of a given OSCAL-based publication. The metadata for previous revisions can be represented as a revision in this object.

define-field.name: version
define-field.description: A string used to distinguish the current version of the document from other previous (and future) versions.

remarks.p: A version string may be a release number, sequence number, date, or other identifier suffcient to distinguish between different document versions. This version is typically set by the document owner or by the tool used to maintain the content.

While not required, it is recommended that OSCAL content authors use Semantic Versioning as a format for version strings. This allows for the easy identification of a version tree consisting of major, minor, and patch numbers.

A publisher of OSCAL content can use this data point along with its siblings published and last-modified to establish a sequence of successive revisions of a given OSCAL-based publication. The metadata for previous revisions can be represented as a revision in this object.

define-field.name: oscal-version
define-field.description: The OSCAL model version the document was authored against.

remarks.p: Indicates the version of the OSCAL model to which this data set conforms, for example 1.1.0 or 1.0.0-M1. That can be used as a hint by a tool to indicate which version of the OSCAL XML or JSON schema to use for validation.

allowed-values.enum: Indicates that the href points to the source resource for the revision entry.

remarks.p: While published, last-modified, oscal-version, and version are not required, values for these entries should be provided if the information is known. For a revision entry to be considered valid, at least one of the following items must be provided: published, last-modified, version, or a link with a rel of source.

define-field.name: document-id
define-field.description: A document identifier qualified by an identifier type.

define-flag.name: scheme
define-flag.description: Qualifies the kind of document identifier.

allowed-values.enum: A Digital Object Identifier (DOI); use is preferred, since this allows for retrieval of a full bibliographic record.

remarks.p: A document identifier or name, qualified by a type that indicates the naming system of the identifier. A document identifier may provide a hint to the persistent location of the same or another version of the document.
Specific usage rules, nomenclatures, and recognized file types (e.g., DOIs, CMS locators, etc.) may be defined at application level. The value of this field may also be a hash or checksum.

allowed-values.enum: Indicates the organization that created this content.
Indicates the organization for which this content was created.
Indicates the organization responsible for all content represented in the "document".

define-assembly.name: location
define-assembly.description: A location, with associated metadata that can be referenced.

define-flag.name: uuid
define-flag.description: A unique identifier that can be used to reference this defined location elsewhere in an OSCAL document. A UUID should be consistantly used for a given location across revisions of the document.

define-field.name: title
define-field.description: A name given to the location, which may be used by a tool for display and navigation.

define-assembly.name: address
define-assembly.description: A postal address for the location.

define-flag.name: location-type
define-flag.description: Indicates the type of address.

allowed-values.enum: A home address.
A work address.

define-field.name: addr-line
define-field.description: A single line of an address.

define-field.name: city
define-field.description: City, town or geographical region for the mailing address.

define-field.name: state
define-field.description: State, province or analogous geographical region for mailing address

define-field.name: postal-code
define-field.description: Postal or ZIP code for mailing address

define-field.name: country
define-field.description: The ISO 3166-1 alpha-2 country code for the mailing address.

define-field.name: email-address
define-field.description: An email address as defined by RFC 5322 Section 3.4.1.

define-field.name: telephone-number
define-field.description: Contact number by telephone.

define-flag.name: type
define-flag.description: Indicates the type of phone number.

allowed-values.enum: A home phone number.
An office phone number.
A mobile phone number.

define-field.name: url
define-field.description: The uniform resource locator (URL) for a web site or Internet presence associated with the location.

define-field.name: location-uuid
define-field.description: References a location defined in metadata.

define-assembly.name: party
define-assembly.description: A responsible entity which is either a person or an organization.

define-flag.name: uuid
define-flag.description: A unique identifier that can be used to reference this defined location elsewhere in an OSCAL document. A UUID should be consistantly used for a given party across revisions of the document.

define-flag.name: type
define-flag.description: A category describing the kind of party the object describes.

allowed-values.enum: An individual.
A group of individuals formed for a specific purpose.

define-field.name: name
define-field.description: The full name of the party. This is typically the legal name associated with the party.

define-field.name: short-name
define-field.description: A short common name, abbreviation, or acronym for the party.

define-field.name: external-id
define-field.description: An identifier for a person or organization using a designated scheme. e.g. an Open Researcher and Contributor ID (ORCID)

define-flag.name: scheme
define-flag.description: Indicates the type of external identifier.

allowed-values.enum: The identifier is Open Researcher and Contributor ID (ORCID).

define-field.name: email-address
define-field.description: An email address as defined by RFC 5322 Section 3.4.1.

define-field.name: telephone-number
define-field.description: Contact number by telephone.

define-flag.name: type
define-flag.description: Indicates the type of phone number.

allowed-values.enum: A home phone number.
An office phone number.
A mobile phone number.

define-assembly.name: address
define-assembly.description: A postal address for the location.

define-flag.name: location-type
define-flag.description: Indicates the type of address.

allowed-values.enum: A home address.
A work address.

define-field.name: addr-line
define-field.description: A single line of an address.

define-field.name: city
define-field.description: City, town or geographical region for the mailing address.

define-field.name: state
define-field.description: State, province or analogous geographical region for mailing address

define-field.name: postal-code
define-field.description: Postal or ZIP code for mailing address

define-field.name: country
define-field.description: The ISO 3166-1 alpha-2 country code for the mailing address.

define-field.name: member-of-organization
define-field.description: Identifies that the party object is a member of the organization associated with the provided UUID.

remarks.p: Parties of both the person or organization type can be associated with an organization using the member-of-organization.

define-field.name: party-uuid
define-field.description: References a party defined in metadata.

define-assembly.name: role
define-assembly.description: Defines a function assumed or expected to be assumed by a party in a specific situation.

define-flag.name: id
define-flag.description: A unique identifier for a specific role instance. This identifier's uniqueness is document scoped and is intended to be consistent for the same role across minor revisions of the document.

remarks.p: OSCAL has defined a set of standardized roles for consistant use in OSCAL documents. This allows tools consuming OSCAL content to infer specific semantics when these roles are used. These roles are documented in the specific contexts of their use (e.g., responsible-party, responsible-role). When using such a role, it is necessary to define these roles in this list, which will then allow such a role to be referenced.

define-field.name: title
define-field.description: A name given to the role, which may be used by a tool for display and navigation.

define-field.name: short-name
define-field.description: A short common name, abbreviation, or acronym for the role.

define-field.name: description
define-field.description: A summary of the role's purpose and associated responsibilities.

remarks.p: Permissible values to be determined closer to the application (e.g. by a receiving authority).

define-field.name: role-id
define-field.description: A reference to the roles served by the user.

define-assembly.name: back-matter
define-assembly.description: A collection of resources, which may be included directly or by reference.

define-assembly.name: resource
define-assembly.description: A resource associated with content in the containing document. A resource may be directly included in the document base64 encoded or may point to one or more equavalent internet resources.

define-flag.name: uuid
define-flag.description: A globally unique identifier that can be used to reference this defined resource elsewhere in an OSCAL document. A UUID should be consistantly used for a given resource across revisions of the document.

define-field.name: title
define-field.description: A name given to the resource, which may be used by a tool for display and navigation.

define-field.name: description
define-field.description: A short summary of the resource used to indicate the purpose of the resource.

define-field.name: document-id
define-field.description: A document identifier qualified by an identifier type.

define-flag.name: scheme
define-flag.description: Qualifies the kind of document identifier.

allowed-values.enum: A Digital Object Identifier (DOI); use is preferred, since this allows for retrieval of a full bibliographic record.

remarks.p: A document identifier or name, qualified by a type that indicates the naming system of the identifier. A document identifier may provide a hint to the persistent location of the same or another version of the document.
Specific usage rules, nomenclatures, and recognized file types (e.g., DOIs, CMS locators, etc.) may be defined at application level. The value of this field may also be a hash or checksum.

define-assembly.name: citation
define-assembly.description: A citation consisting of end note text and optional structured bibliographic data.

define-field.name: text
define-field.description: A line of citation text.

define-assembly.name: biblio
define-assembly.description: A container for structured bibliographic information. The model of this information is undefined by OSCAL.

remarks.p: The text is used to define the endnote text, without any required bibliographic structure. If structured bibliographic data is needed, then the biblio can be used for this purpose.
A biblio can be used to capture a structured bibliograpical citation in an appropriate format.

define-assembly.name: rlink
define-assembly.description: A pointer to an external resource with an optional hash for verification and change detection.

define-flag.name: href
define-flag.description: A resolvable URI reference to a resource.

remarks.p: When appearing as part of a resource/rlink, the hash applies to the resource referenced by the href.
This construct is different from link, which makes no provision for a hash or formal title.

Multiple rlink can be included for a resource. In such a case, all provided rlink items are intended to be equivalent in content, but may differ in structure. A media-type is used to identify the format of a given rlink, and can be used to differentiate a items in a collection of rlinks. The media-type also provides a hint to the OSCAL document consumer about the structure of the resource referenced by the rlink.

define-field.name: base64
define-field.description: The Base64 alphabet in RFC 2045 - aligned with XSD.

define-flag.name: filename
define-flag.description: Name of the file before it was encoded as Base64 to be embedded in a resource. This is the name that will be assigned to the file when the file is decoded.

allowed-values.enum: TODO: (Brian)
TODO: (Brian)
TODO: (Brian)
TODO: (Brian)

remarks.p: Ensures that each rlink item references a unique resource.
Ensures that all base64 resources have a unique filename.
A title is required when a citation is provided.

A resource can be used in two ways. 1) it may point to an specific retrievable network resource using a rlink, or 2) it may be included as an attachment using a base64. A resource may contain multiple rlink and base64 entries that represent alternative download locations (rlink) and attachments (base64) for the same resource. Both rlink and base64 allow for a media-type to be specified, which is used to distiguish between different representations of the same resource (e.g., Microsoft Word, PDF). When multiple rlink and base64 items are included for a given resource, all items must contain equivalent information. This allows the document consumer to choose a preferred item to process based on a the selected item's media-type. This is extremely important when the items represent OSCAL content that is represented in alternate formats (i.e., XML, JSON, YAML), allowing the same OSCAL data to be processed from any of the available formats indicated by the items.
When a resource includes a citation, then the title and citation properties must both be included.

Provides a collection of identified resource objects that can be referenced by a link with a rel value of "reference" and an href value that is a fragment "#" followed by a reference to a reference identifier.

example.description: Use of link, citation, and resource

remarks.p: The following is a contrived example to show the use of link, citation, and resource.

define-field.name: property
define-field.description: An attribute, characteristic, or quality of the containing object expressed as a namespace qualified name/value pair. The value of a property is a simple scalar value, which may be expressed as a list of values in some OSCAL formats.

define-flag.name: uuid
define-flag.description: A unique identifier that can be used to reference this property elsewhere in an OSCAL document. A UUID should be consistantly used for a given location across revisions of the document.

define-flag.name: name
define-flag.description: A textual label that uniquely identifies a specific attribute, characteristic, or quality of the property's containing object.

allowed-values.enum: A label or descriptor that is tied to a sensitivity or classification marking system. An optional class can be used to define the specific marking system used for the associated value.

define-flag.name: ns
define-flag.description: A namespace qualifying the property's name. This allows different organizations to associate distinct semantics with the same name.

remarks.p: Provides a means to segment the value space for the name, so that different organizations and individuals can assert control over the allowed names and associated values used in a property. This allows the semantics associated with a given name/value pair to be defined on an organization-by-organization basis.
An organization MUST use a URI that they have control over. e.g., a domain registered to the organization in a URI, a registered uniform resource names (URN) namespace.
When a ns is not provided, its value should be assumed to be http://csrc.nist.gov/ns/oscal and the name should be a name defined by the associated OSCAL model.

define-flag.name: class
define-flag.description: A textual label that provides a sub-type or characterization of the property's name. This can be used to further distinguish or discriminate between the semantics of multiple properties of the same object with the same name and ns.

remarks.p: A class can be used in validation rules to express extra constraints over named items of a specific class value.

Properties permit the deployment and management of arbitrary controlled values, within OSCAL objects. A property can be included for any purpose useful to an application or implementation. Typically, properties will be used to sort, filter, select, order, and arrange OSCAL content objects, to relate OSCAL objects to one another, or to associate an OSCAL object to class hierarchies, taxonomies, or external authorities. Thus, the lexical composition of properties may be constrained by external processes to ensure consistency.

define-assembly.name: annotation
define-assembly.description: An attribute, characteristic, or quality of the containing object expressed as a namespace qualified name/value pair with optional explanatory remarks. The value of an annotated property is a simple scalar value.

define-flag.name: name
define-flag.description: A textual label that uniquely identifies a specific attribute, characteristic, or quality of the annotated property's containing object.

define-flag.name: uuid
define-flag.description: A unique identifier that can be used to reference this annotated property elsewhere in an OSCAL document. A UUID should be consistantly used for a given location across revisions of the document.

define-flag.name: ns
define-flag.description: A namespace qualifying the annotated property's name. This allows different organizations to associate distinct semantics with the same name.

remarks.p: Provides a means to segment the value space for the name, so that different organizations and individuals can assert control over the allowed names and associated values used in an annotated property. This allows the semantics associated with a given name/value pair to be defined on an organization-by-organization basis.
An organization MUST use a URI that they have control over. e.g., a domain registered to the organization in a URI, a registered uniform resource names (URN) namespace.
When a ns is not provided, its value should be assumed to be http://csrc.nist.gov/ns/oscal and the name should be a name defined by the associated OSCAL model.

define-flag.name: value
define-flag.description: Indicates the value of the attribute, characteristic, or quality.

remarks.p: Annotated property and property have a similar model. Both permit the deployment and management of arbitrary controlled values, within OSCAL objects. Similar to a property, an annotated property can be included for any purpose useful to an application or implementation. Typically, annotated properties will be used to sort, filter, select, order, and arrange OSCAL content objects, to relate OSCAL objects to one another, or to associate an OSCAL object to class hierarchies, taxonomies, or external authorities. Thus, the lexical composition of annotated properties may be constrained by external processes to ensure consistency.

Unlike a property, an annotated property allows for associated remarks that describe why the specific annotation value was applied to the containing object, or the significance of the annotation value in the context of the containing object.

define-assembly.name: link
define-assembly.description: A reference to a local or remote resource

define-flag.name: href
define-flag.description: A resolvable URL reference to a resource.

remarks.p: The value of the href can be an internet resource, or a local reference using a fragment e.g. #fragment that points to a back-matter resource in the same document.

If a local reference using a fragment is used, this will be indicated by a fragment "#" followed by an identifier which references an identified resource in the document's back-matter or another object that is within the scope of the containing OSCAL document.

If an internet resource is used, the href value will be an absolute or relative URI pointing to the location of the referenced resource. A relative URI will be resolved relative to the location of the document containing the link.

define-flag.name: rel
define-flag.description: Describes the type of relationship provided by the link. This can be an indicator of the link's purpose.

allowed-values.enum: Reference

remarks.p: The media-type provides a hint about the content model of the referenced resource. A valid entry from the IANA Media Types registry SHOULD be used.

define-field.name: text
define-field.description: A textual label to associate with the link, which may be used for presentation in a tool.

remarks.p: To provide a cryptographic hash for a remote target resource, a local reference to a back matter resource is needed. The resource allows one or more hash values to be provided using the rlink/hash object.
The OSCAL link is a roughly based on the HTML link element.
The following is a contrived example to show the use of link, citation, and resource.

define-assembly.name: responsible-party
define-assembly.description: A reference to a set of organizations or persons that have responsibility for performing a referenced role in the context of the containing object.

define-flag.name: role-id
define-flag.description: The role that the party is responsible for.

remarks.p: Specifies one or more parties that are responsible for performing the associated role.

define-field.name: hash
define-field.description: A representation of a cryptographic digest generated over a resource using a specified hash algorithm.

define-flag.name: algorithm
define-flag.description: Method by which a hash is derived

allowed-values.enum: The SHA-224 algorithm as defined by NIST FIPS 180-4.
The SHA-256 algorithm as defined by NIST FIPS 180-4.
The SHA-384 algorithm as defined by NIST FIPS 180-4.
The SHA-512 algorithm as defined by NIST FIPS 180-4.
The SHA3-224 algorithm as defined by NIST FIPS 202.
The SHA3-256 algorithm as defined by NIST FIPS 202.
The SHA3-384 algorithm as defined by NIST FIPS 202.
The SHA3-512 algorithm as defined by NIST FIPS 202.

remarks.p: Any other value used MUST be a value defined in the W3C XML Security Algorithm Cross-Reference Digest Methods (W3C, April 2013) or RFC 6931 Section 2.1.5 New SHA Functions.
A hash value can be used to authenticate that a referenced resource is the same resources as was pointed to by the author of the reference.

define-flag.name: media-type
define-flag.description: Specifies a media type as defined by the Internet Assigned Numbers Authority (IANA) Media Types Registry.

define-field.name: remarks
define-field.description: Additional commentary on the containing object.

define-assembly.name: system-component
define-assembly.description: A defined component that can be part of an implemented system.

define-flag.name: uuid
define-flag.description: The unique identifier for the component.

define-field.name: title
define-field.description: A human readable name for the system component.

define-field.name: description
define-field.description: A description of the component, including information about its function.

define-field.name: purpose
define-field.description: A summary of the technological or business purpose of the component.

define-assembly.name: status
define-assembly.description: Describes the operational status of the system component.

define-flag.name: state
define-flag.description: The operational status.

allowed-values.enum: The component is being designed, developed, or implemented.
The component is currently operational and is available for use in the system.
The component is no longer operational.
Some other state.

remarks.p: Used for service components to define the protocols supported by the service.

allowed-values.enum: Identifies if the component is intended to be publicly accessible (yes/no)
Identifies if the component is virtualized (yes/no)
Virtual LAN identifier of the component.
An asset tag that is unique within the organization for the component.
Title of the Interconnection Security Agreement (ISA).
Date of the Interconnection Security Agreement (ISA).
The name of the remote interconnected system.
Reletave placement of component ('inteneral' or 'external') to the system.
UUID of the related leveraged-authorization assembly in this SSP.
UUID of the component as it was assigned in the leveraged system's SSP.
The version of the component.
The specific patch level of the component.
The model of the component.
The date the component was released, such as a software release date or policy publication date.
Simple description of the component's function, such as Router, Storage Array, DNS Server.
The physical location of the component's hardware (e.g., Data Center ID, Cage#, Rack#, or other meaningful location identifiers).
The name of the baseline configuration for the component.
Can the component be check with an authenticated scan? (yes/no)
The function provided by the component for the system.
A link to the system interconnection agreement.
A reference to another component that this component has a dependency on.
A reference to another component of type=validation, that is a validation (e.g., FIPS 140-2) for this component
A pointer to a validation record (e.g., FIPS 140-2) or other compliance information.
A reference to the baseline template used to configure the asset.
This service is used by the referenced component identifier.
A link to the system security plan of the external system.
Interconnection Security Agreement (ISA) point of contact (POC) for this system.
Interconnection Security Agreement (ISA) point of contact (POC) for the remote interconnected system.
Interconnection Security Agreement (ISA) authorizing official for this system.
Interconnection Security Agreement (ISA) authorizing official for the remote interconnected system.
Accountable for ensuring the asset is managed in accordance with organizational policies and procedures.
Responsible for administering a set of assets.
Members of the security operations center (SOC).
Members of the network operations center (NOC).
Responsible for responding to an event that could lead to loss of, or disruption to, an organization's operations, services or functions.
Responsible for providing information and support to users.
Responsible for the configuration management processes governing changes to the asset.
Responsible for the creation and maintenance of a component.
Organization responsible for providing the component, if this is different from the "maintainer" (e.g., a reseller).
The component is publicly accessible.
The component is not publicly accessible.
The component is virtualized.
The component is not virtualized.
The component is implemented within the system boundary.
The component is implemented outside the system boundary.
If a "software" component-type, the identifier, such as a SWID tag, for the software component.
The component allows an authenticated scan.
The component does not allow an authenticated scan.
This service is provided by the referenced component identifier.

remarks.p: Components may be products, services, application programming interface (APIs), policies, processes, plans, guidance, standards, or other tangible items that enable security and/or privacy.
The type indicates which of these component types is represented.

When defining a service compoenent where are relationship to other components is known, one or more link entries with rel values of provided-by and used-by can be used to link to the specific component identifer(s) that provide and use the service respectively.

define-flag.name: component-type
define-flag.description: A category describing the purpose of the component.

allowed-values.enum: The system as a whole.
Any software, operating system, or firmware.
A service that may provide APIs.
A connection to something outside this system.
Any guideline or recommendation.
An external assessment performed on some other component, that has been validated by a third-party.

define-assembly.name: protocol
define-assembly.description: Information about the protocol used to provide a service.

define-flag.name: uuid
define-flag.formal-name: Service Protocol Information Universally Unique Identifier
define-flag.description: A globally unique identifier that can be used to reference this service protocol entry elsewhere in an OSCAL document. A UUID should be consistantly used for a given resource across revisions of the document.

define-flag.name: name
define-flag.description: The common name of the protocol, which should be the appropriate "service name" from the IANA Service Name and Transport Protocol Port Number Registry.

remarks.p: The short name of the protocol (e.g., https).

define-field.name: title
define-field.description: A human readable name for the protocol (e.g., Transport Layer Security).

define-field.name: port-range
define-field.description: Where applicable this is the IPv4 port range on which the service operates.

define-flag.name: start
define-flag.description: Indicates the starting port number in a port range

remarks.p: Should be a number within a permitted range

define-flag.name: end
define-flag.description: Indicates the ending port number in a port range

remarks.p: Should be a number within a permitted range

define-flag.name: transport
define-flag.description: Indicates the transport type.

allowed-values.enum: Transmission Control Protocol
User Datagram Protocol

remarks.p: To be validated as a natural number (integer >= 1). A single port uses the same value for start and end. Use multiple 'port-range' entries for non-contiguous ranges.

define-assembly.name: system-user
define-assembly.description: A type of user that interacts with the system based on an associated role.

define-flag.name: uuid
define-flag.description: The unique identifier for the user class.

define-field.name: title
define-field.description: A name given to the user, which may be used by a tool for display and navigation.

define-field.name: short-name
define-field.description: A short common name, abbreviation, or acronym for the user.

define-field.name: description
define-field.description: A summary of the user's purpose within the system.

allowed-values.enum: The type of user, such as internal, external, or general-public.
The user's privilege level within the system, such as privileged, non-privileged, no-logical-access.
TODO
TODO
TODO
TODO
TODO
TODO
Accountable for ensuring the asset is managed in accordance with organizational policies and procedures.
Responsible for administering a set of assets.
Members of the security operations center (SOC).
Members of the network operations center (NOC).
Responsible for responding to an event that could lead to loss of, or disruption to, an organization's operations, services or functions.
Responsible for providing information and support to users.
Responsible for the configuration management processes governing changes to the asset.

remarks.p: Permissible values to be determined closer to the application, such as by a receiving authority.

define-assembly.name: authorized-privilege
define-assembly.description: Identifies a specific system privilege held by the user, along with an associated description and/or rationale for the privilege.

define-field.name: title
define-field.description: A human readable name for the privilege.

define-field.name: description
define-field.description: A summary of the privilege's purpose within the system.

define-field.name: function-performed
define-field.description: Describes a function performed for a given authorized privilege by this user class.

define-assembly.name: inventory-item
define-assembly.description: A single managed inventory item within the system.

define-flag.name: uuid
define-flag.description: A globally unique identifier that can be used to reference this inventory item entry elsewhere in an OSCAL document. A UUID should be consistantly used for a given resource across revisions of the document.

define-flag.name: asset-id
define-flag.description: Organizational asset identifier that is unique in the context of the system. This may be a reference to the identifier used in an asset tracking system or a vulnerability scanning tool.

define-field.name: description
define-field.description: A summary of the inventory item stating its purpose within the system.

allowed-values.enum: Identifies whether the asset is publicly accessible (yes/no)
Identifies whether the asset is virtualized (yes/no)
Virtual LAN identifier of the asset.
An asset tag that is unique within the organization for the component.
The Internet Protocol v4 Address of the asset.
The Internet Protocol v6 Address of the asset.
The network identifier of the asset.
The full-qualified domain name (FQDN) of the asset.
A Uniform Resource Identifier (URI) for the asset.
A serial number for the asset.
The NetBIOS name for the asset.
The media access control (MAC) address for the asset.
The name of the operating system used by the asset.
The version of the operating system used by the asset.
Simple description of the asset's function, such as Router, Storage Array, DNS Server.
The model number of the hardware used by the asset.
The software product name used by the asset.
The software product version used by the asset.
The software product patch level used by the asset.
The name of the baseline configuration for the asset.
is the asset subjected to network scans? (yes/no)
Can the asset be check with an authenticated scan? (yes/no)
The physical location of the asset's hardware (e.g., Data Center ID, Cage#, Rack#, or other meaningful location identifiers).
The function provided by the asset for the system.
A reference to the baseline template used to configure the asset.
Accountable for ensuring the asset is managed in accordance with organizational policies and procedures.
Responsible for administering a set of assets.
Members of the security operations center (SOC).
Members of the network operations center (NOC).
Responsible for responding to an event that could lead to loss of, or disruption to, an organization's operations, services or functions.
Responsible for providing information and support to users.
Responsible for the configuration management processes governing changes to the asset.
Responsible for the creation and maintenance of a component.
Organization responsible for providing the component, if this is different from the "maintainer" (e.g., a reseller).

define-assembly.name: implemented-component
define-assembly.description: The set of componenets that are implemented in a given system inventory item.

define-flag.name: component-uuid
define-flag.description: A reference to a component that is implemented as part of an inventory item.

define-flag.name: use
define-flag.description: The type of implementation

allowed-values.enum: The implemented component is a 'software' component that the inventory item has installed and uses.
The implemented component is a 'hardware' component that the inventory item has installed and uses.
The implemented component is a 'policy' component that the inventory item supports and enforces.
The implemented component is a 'process' component that the inventory item supports and enforces.

remarks.p: This construct is used to either: 1) associate a party or parties to a role defined on the component using the responsible-role construct, or 2) to define a party or parties that are responsible for a role defined within the context of the containing inventory-item.

allowed-values.enum: Identifies whether the asset is publicly accessible (yes/no)
Identifies whether the asset is virtualized (yes/no)
The Internet Protocol v4 Address of the asset.
The Internet Protocol v6 Address of the asset.
Virtual LAN identifier of the asset.
The network identifier of the asset.
The full-qualified domain name (FQDN) of the asset.
A Uniform Resource Identifier (URI) for the asset.
A serial number for the asset.
An asset tag that is unique within the organization for the asset.
The NetBIOS name for the asset.
The media access control (MAC) address for the asset.
Simple description of the asset's function (e.g., Router, Storage Array, DNS Server, etc.).
The name of the baseline configuration for the asset.
is the asset subjected to network scans? (yes/no)
Can the asset be check with an authenticated scan? (yes/no)
The physical location of the asset's hardware (e.g., Data Center ID, Cage#, Rack#, or other meaningful location identifiers).
The function provided by the asset for the system.
A reference to the baseline template used to configure the asset.
Accountable for ensuring the asset is managed in accordance with organizational policies and procedures.
Responsible for administering a set of assets.
Members of the security operations center (SOC).
Members of the network operations center (NOC).
Members of the incident response team.
Members of the help desk.
Responsible for the configuration management processes governing changes to the asset.
Organization responsible for the creation and maintenance of the component.
Organization responsible for providing the component, if this is different from the "maintainer" (e.g., a reseller).

define-flag.name: source
define-flag.description: A reference to an OSCAL catalog or profile providing the referenced control or subcontrol definition.

define-flag.name: control-id
define-flag.description: A reference to a control identifier.

define-assembly.name: only-statement
define-assembly.description: Describes which specific statements are addressed by a requirement, by pointing to a specific requirement statement within a control.

remarks.p: A reference to the specific implemented statement.

define-field.name: description
define-field.description: A description of the component, including information about its function.

define-flag.name: statement-id
define-flag.description: A reference to a control statement by its identifier

define-assembly.name: responsible-role
define-assembly.description: A reference to one or more roles with responsibility for performing a function relative to the containing object.

define-flag.name: role-id
define-flag.description: The role that is responsible for the business function.

define-assembly.name: set-parameter
define-assembly.description: Identifies the parameter that will be set by the enclosed value.

define-field.name: parameter-value
define-field.description: A parameter value or set of values.

define-field.name: system-id
define-field.description: A unique identifier for the system described by this system security plan.

define-flag.name: identifier-type
define-flag.description: Identifies the identification system from which the provided identifier was assigned.

allowed-values.enum: The identifier was assigned by FedRAMP.
A Universally Unique IDentifier (UUID) as defined by RFC4122.

define-flag.name: param-id
define-flag.description: A reference to a parameter within a control, who's catalog has been imported into the current implementation context.

define-assembly.name: system-security-plan
define-assembly.description: A system security plan, such as those described in NIST SP 800-18

define-flag.name: uuid
define-flag.formal-name: System Security Plan Universally Unique Identifier
define-flag.description: A globally unique identifier for this catalog instance. This UUID should be changed when this document is revised.

define-assembly.name: import-profile
define-assembly.description: Used to import the OSCAL profile representing the system's control baseline.

define-flag.name: href
define-flag.description: A resolvable URL reference to the profile to use as the system's control baseline.

remarks.p: The value of the href can be an internet resource, or a local reference using a fragment e.g. #fragment that points to a back-matter resource in the same document.

If a local reference using a fragment is used, this will be indicated by a fragment "#" followed by an identifier which references an identified resource in the document's back-matter or another object that is within the scope of the containing OSCAL document.

If an internet resource is used, the href value will be an absolute or relative URI pointing to the location of the referenced resource. A relative URI will be resolved relative to the location of the document containing the link.

define-assembly.name: system-characteristics
define-assembly.description: Contains the characteristics of the system, such as its name, purpose, and security impact level.

define-field.name: system-name
define-field.description: The full name of the system.

define-field.name: system-name-short
define-field.description: A short name for the system, such as an acronym, that is suitable for display in a data table or summary list.

define-field.name: description
define-field.description: A summary of the system.

define-field.name: date-authorized
define-field.description: The date the system received its authorization.

define-field.name: security-sensitivity-level
define-field.description: The overall information system sensitivity categorization, such as defined by FIPS-199.

remarks.p: Often, organizations require the security sensitivity level to correspond with the highest confidentiality, integrity, or availability level identified by security-impact-level.

allowed-values.enum: A value of 1, 2, or 3 as defined by SP 800-63-3.
A value of 1, 2, or 3 as defined by SP 800-63-3.
A value of 1, 2, or 3 as defined by SP 800-63-3.
As defined by SP 800-63-3.
As defined by SP 800-63-3.
As defined by SP 800-63-3.
The associated value is one of: public-cloud, private-cloud, community-cloud, government-only-cloud, hybrid-cloud, or other.
The associated value is one of: saas, paas, iaas, or other.
The public cloud deployment model as defined by The NIST Definition of Cloud Computing.
The private cloud deployment model as defined by The NIST Definition of Cloud Computing.
The community cloud deployment model as defined by The NIST Definition of Cloud Computing.
TODO: define
Any other type of cloud deployment model that is exclusive to the other choices.

remarks.p: The hybrid cloud deployment model, as defined by The NIST Definition of Cloud Computing, can be supported by selecting two or more of the existing deployment models.

allowed-values.enum: Software as a service (SaaS) cloud service model as defined by The NIST Definition of Cloud Computing.
Platform as a service (PaaS) cloud service model as defined by The NIST Definition of Cloud Computing.
Infrastructure as a service (IaaS) cloud service model as defined by The NIST Definition of Cloud Computing.
Any other type of cloud service model that is exclusive to the other choices.
The authorizing official for this system.
The authorizing official's designated point of contact (POC) for this system.
The executive ultimately accountable for the system.
The primary management-level point of contact (POC) for the system.
The primary technical point of contact (POC) for the system.
Other point of contact (POC) for the system that is not the management or technical POC.
The primary role responsible for ensuring the organization operates the system securely.
The point of contact (POC) responsible for identifying privacy information within the system, and ensuring its protection if present.

define-assembly.name: system-information
define-assembly.description: Contains details about all information types that are stored, processed, or transmitted by the system, such as privacy information, and those defined in NIST SP 800-60.

define-assembly.name: information-type
define-assembly.description: Contains details about one information type that is stored, processed, or transmitted by the system, such as privacy information, and those defined in NIST SP 800-60.

define-flag.name: uuid
define-flag.description: A globally unique identifier that can be used to reference this information type entry elsewhere in an OSCAL document. A UUID should be consistantly used for a given resource across revisions of the document.

define-field.name: title
define-field.description: A human readable name for the information type. This title should be meaningful within the context of the system.

define-field.name: description
define-field.description: A summary of how this information type is used within the system.

define-field.name: information-type-id
define-field.description: An identifier qualified by the given identification system used, such as NIST SP 800-60.

define-flag.name: system
define-flag.description: Specifies the information type identification system used.

allowed-values.enum: Based on the section identifiers in NIST Special Publication 800-60 Volume II Revision 1

remarks.p: The current allowed values are based on those identified in NIST SP 800-60 Volume 2

define-assembly.name: confidentiality-impact
define-assembly.description: The expected level of impact resulting from the unauthorized disclosure of information.

define-field.name: base
define-field.description: The prescribed base (Confidentiality, Integrity, or Availability) security impact level.

define-field.name: selected
define-field.description: The selected (Confidentiality, Integrity, or Availability) security impact level.

define-field.name: adjustment-justification
define-field.description: If the selected security level is different from the base security level, this contains the justification for the change.

define-assembly.name: integrity-impact
define-assembly.description: The expected level of impact resulting from the unauthorized modification of information.

define-field.name: base
define-field.description: The prescribed base (Confidentiality, Integrity, or Availability) security impact level.

define-field.name: selected
define-field.description: The selected (Confidentiality, Integrity, or Availability) security impact level.

define-field.name: adjustment-justification
define-field.description: If the selected security level is different from the base security level, this contains the justification for the change.

define-assembly.name: availability-impact
define-assembly.description: The expected level of impact resulting from the disruption of access to or use of information or the information system.

define-field.name: base
define-field.description: The prescribed base (Confidentiality, Integrity, or Availability) security impact level.

define-field.name: selected
define-field.description: The selected (Confidentiality, Integrity, or Availability) security impact level.

define-field.name: adjustment-justification
define-field.description: If the selected security level is different from the base security level, this contains the justification for the change.

allowed-values.enum: Is this a privacy sensitive system? yes or no
The system is privacy sensitive.
The system isnot privacy sensitive.
A link to the privacy impact assessment.
A 'low' sensitivity level as defined in FIPS-199.
A 'moderate' sensitivity level as defined in FIPS-199.
A 'high' sensitivity level as defined in FIPS-199.

remarks.p: FIPS-199 taxonomy is provided here as a starting point. We will provide other taxonomies based on community requests.

define-assembly.name: security-impact-level
define-assembly.description: The overall level of expected impact resulting from unauthorized disclosure, modification, or loss of access to information.

define-field.name: security-objective-confidentiality
define-field.description: A target-level of confidentiality for the system, based on the sensitivity of information within the system.

define-field.name: security-objective-integrity
define-field.description: A target-level of integrity for the system, based on the sensitivity of information within the system.

define-field.name: security-objective-availability
define-field.description: A target-level of availability for the system, based on the sensitivity of information within the system.

define-assembly.name: status
define-assembly.description: Describes the operational status of the system.

define-flag.name: state
define-flag.description: The current operating status.

allowed-values.enum: The system is currently operating in production.
The system is being designed, developed, or implemented
The system is undergoing a major change, development, or transition.
The system is no longer operational.
Some other state.

remarks.p: If 'other' is selected, a remark must be included to describe the current state.

define-assembly.name: authorization-boundary
define-assembly.description: A description of this system's authorization boundary, optionally supplemented by diagrams that illustrate the authorization boundary.

define-field.name: description
define-field.description: A summary of the system's authorization boundary.

remarks.p: A visual depiction of the system's authorization boundary.

define-field.name: remarks
define-field.description: Commentary about the system's authorization boundary that enhances the diagram.

define-assembly.name: diagram
define-assembly.description: A graphic that provides a visual representation the system, or some aspect of it.

define-flag.name: uuid
define-flag.description: The identifier for this diagram.

define-field.name: description
define-field.description: A summary of the diagram.

remarks.p: This description is intended to be used as alternate text to support compliance with requirements from Section 508 of the United States Workforce Rehabilitation Act of 1973.

define-field.name: caption
define-field.description: A brief caption to annotate the diagram.

define-field.name: remarks
define-field.description: Commentary about the diagram that enhances it.

allowed-values.enum: A reference to the diagram image.

remarks.p: A diagram must include a link with a rel value of "diagram", who's href references a remote URI or an internal reference within this document containing the diagram.
The internal reference "#diagram1" points to an attached resource defined in the back-matter as a resource. The media-type indicates that the image is a Portable Network Graphics (PNG) image.

define-assembly.name: network-architecture
define-assembly.description: A description of the system's network architecture, optionally supplemented by diagrams that illustrate the network architecture.

define-field.name: description
define-field.description: A summary of the system's network architecture.

define-assembly.name: data-flow
define-assembly.description: A description of the logical flow of information within the system and across its boundaries, optionally supplemented by diagrams that illustrate these flows.

define-field.name: description
define-field.description: A summary of the system's data flow.

define-assembly.name: system-implementation
define-assembly.description: Provides information as to how the system is implemented.

define-assembly.name: leveraged-authorization
define-assembly.description: A description of another authorized system from which this system inherits capabilities that satisfy security requirements. Another term for this concept is a common control provider.

define-flag.name: uuid
define-flag.description: A globally unique identifier that can be used to reference this leveraged authorization entry elsewhere in an OSCAL document. A UUID should be consistantly used for a given resource across revisions of the document.

define-field.name: title
define-field.description: A human readable name for the leveraged authorization in the context of the system.

define-field.name: party-uuid
define-field.description: A reference to the party that manages the leveraged system.

define-field.name: date-authorized
define-field.description: The date the system received its authorization.

allowed-values.enum: A reference to the system security plan for the leveraged authorization.

define-assembly.name: system-inventory
define-assembly.description: A set of inventory-item entries that represent the managed inventory instances of the system.

define-assembly.name: control-implementation
define-assembly.description: Describes how the system satisfies a set of controls.

define-field.name: description
define-field.description: A statement describing important things to know about how this set of control satisfaction documentation is approached.

define-assembly.name: implemented-requirement
define-assembly.description: Describes how the system satisfies an individual control.

define-flag.name: uuid
define-flag.description: A globally unique identifier that can be used to reference this control requirement entry elsewhere in an OSCAL document. A UUID should be consistantly used for a given resource across revisions of the document.

allowed-values.enum: Accountable for ensuring the asset is managed in accordance with organizational policies and procedures.
Responsible for administering a set of assets.
Members of the security operations center (SOC).
Members of the network operations center (NOC).
Responsible for responding to an event that could lead to loss of, or disruption to, an organization's operations, services or functions.
Responsible for providing information and support to users.
Responsible for the configuration management processes governing changes to the asset.

define-assembly.name: statement
define-assembly.description: Identifies which statements within a control are addressed.

remarks.p: A reference to the specific implemented statement associated with a control.

define-flag.name: uuid
define-flag.formal-name: Control Statement Reference Universally Unique Identifier
define-flag.description: A globally unique identifier that can be used to reference this control statement entry elsewhere in an OSCAL document. A UUID should be consistantly used for a given resource across revisions of the document.

allowed-values.enum: Accountable for ensuring the asset is managed in accordance with organizational policies and procedures.
Responsible for administering a set of assets.
Members of the security operations center (SOC).
Members of the network operations center (NOC).
Responsible for responding to an event that could lead to loss of, or disruption to, an organization's operations, services or functions.
Responsible for providing information and support to users.
Responsible for the configuration management processes governing changes to the asset.

define-assembly.name: by-component
define-assembly.description: Defines how the referenced component implements a set of controls.

define-flag.name: component-uuid
define-flag.description: A reference to the component that is implementing a given control or control statement.

define-flag.name: uuid
define-flag.description: A globally unique identifier that can be used to reference this by-component entry elsewhere in an OSCAL document. A UUID should be consistantly used for a given resource across revisions of the document.

define-field.name: description
define-field.description: An implementation statement that describes how a control or a control statement is implemented within the referenced system component.

define-assembly.name: export
define-assembly.description: Identifies content intended for external consumption, such as with leveraged organizations.

define-field.name: description
define-field.description: An implementation statement that describes the aspects of the control or control statement implementation that can be available to another system leveraging this system.

define-assembly.name: provided
define-assembly.description: Describes a capability which may be inherited by a leveraging system.

define-flag.name: uuid
define-flag.description: A globally unique identifier that can be used to reference this provided entry elsewhere in an OSCAL document. A UUID should be consistantly used for a given resource across revisions of the document.

define-field.name: description
define-field.description: An implementation statement that describes the aspects of the control or control statement implementation that can be provided to another system leveraging this system.

define-assembly.name: responsibility
define-assembly.description: Describes a control implementation responsibiity imposed on a leveraging system.

define-flag.name: uuid
define-flag.description: A globally unique identifier that can be used to reference this responsibility entry elsewhere in an OSCAL document. A UUID should be consistantly used for a given resource across revisions of the document.

define-flag.name: provided-uuid
define-flag.description: Identifies a 'provided' assembly associated with this assembly.

define-field.name: description
define-field.description: An implementation statement that describes the aspects of the control or control statement implementation that a leveraging system must implement to satisfy the control provided by a leveraged system.

define-assembly.name: inherited
define-assembly.description: Describes a control implementation inherited by a leveraging system.

define-flag.name: uuid
define-flag.description: A globally unique identifier that can be used to reference this inherited entry elsewhere in an OSCAL document. A UUID should be consistantly used for a given resource across revisions of the document.

define-flag.name: provided-uuid
define-flag.description: Identifies a 'provided' assembly associated with this assembly.

define-field.name: description
define-field.description: An implementation statement that describes the aspects of a control or control statement implementation that a leveraging system is inheriting from a leveraged system.

define-assembly.name: satisfied
define-assembly.description: Describes how this system satisfies a responsibiity imposed by a leveraged system.

define-flag.name: uuid
define-flag.description: A globally unique identifier that can be used to reference this satisfied entry elsewhere in an OSCAL document. A UUID should be consistantly used for a given resource across revisions of the document.

define-flag.name: responsibility-uuid
define-flag.description: Identifies a 'provided' assembly associated with this assembly.

define-field.name: description
define-field.description: An implementation statement that describes the aspects of a control or control statement implementation that a leveraging system is implementing based on a requirement from a leveraged system.

allowed-values.enum: Accountable for ensuring the asset is managed in accordance with organizational policies and procedures.
Responsible for administering a set of assets.
Members of the security operations center (SOC).
Members of the network operations center (NOC).
Responsible for responding to an event that could lead to loss of, or disruption to, an organization's operations, services or functions.
Responsible for providing information and support to users.
Responsible for the configuration management processes governing changes to the asset.
Responsible for the creation and maintenance of a component.
Organization responsible for providing the component, if this is different from the "maintainer" (e.g., a reseller).
